description:
Aspergillus mulundensis is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Mulund, a suburb of Mumbai, India.

Aspergillus mulundensis is characterized by its colony morphology, which appears as dense, velvety, and dark green in color on various culture media. Microscopically, the fungus produces conidiophores (specialized reproductive structures) that bear globose vesicles, which give rise to uniseriate phialides (spore-bearing structures) that produce chains of conidial spores (asexual spores).

Genetically, Aspergillus mulundensis is closely related to other members of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which includes several clinically important species. However, Aspergillus mulundensis is not known to be a significant human pathogen, and its ecological role and potential applications in biotechnology or other fields are still under investigation.
